stem: The nurse is participating in a staff meeting regarding hospital digital ethics and social media conduct. Which behaviors on personal social media accounts are considered unprofessional or a violation of safety standards in nursing?

options.text: Criticizing a named colleague on a public Facebook post regarding their clinical skills.
Sharing an official public health announcement from the CDC on a personal page.
Informing the employer (HR) about a co-worker who posted pictures of patient care on Instagram.
Sharing a petition for improved nurse-to-patient ratios while identifying as a nurse.
A nurse 'stalking' or repeatedly commenting on a former patient's personal photos.
Posting a story about a 'difficult patient' using a code name instead of a real name.

rationale.correct: Professionalism extends to the digital sphere. (A) Lateral violence/cyber-bullying of colleagues is unprofessional and can impact unit safety. (C) Pursuing personal relationships with patients digitally violates professional boundaries. (D) Even with 'code names,' the context of the story may identify the patient (Jigsaw effect), violating HIPAA.
rationale.incorrect: (B) Nurses have a right to engage in political advocacy for patient safety. (E) Sharing factual, official public health data is a positive use of social media. (F) Reporting a privacy violation is a professional responsibility, not a violation.

answerBreakdown.label: A
answerBreakdown.content: Identifying "Criticizing a named colleague on a public Facebook post regarding their clinical skills." is a priority nursing action/finding essential for maintaining patient safety in this scenario.

answerBreakdown.label: B
answerBreakdown.content: While plausible in other contexts, "Sharing an official public health announcement from the CDC on a personal page." is not the highest priority or most relevant factor in this acute scenario.

answerBreakdown.label: C
answerBreakdown.content: While plausible in other contexts, "Informing the employer (HR) about a co-worker who posted pictures of patient care on Instagram." is not the highest priority or most relevant factor in this acute scenario.

answerBreakdown.label: D
answerBreakdown.content: Choosing "Sharing a petition for improved nurse-to-patient ratios while identifying as a nurse." represents a misinterpretation of the gathered cues or a failure to prioritize physiological needs.

answerBreakdown.label: E
answerBreakdown.content: Clinically, "A nurse 'stalking' or repeatedly commenting on a former patient's personal photos." is the most appropriate finding pointing toward the suspected condition and requiring intervention.

answerBreakdown.label: F
answerBreakdown.content: Selecting "Posting a story about a 'difficult patient' using a code name instead of a real name." is evidence-based as it directly correlates with the primary clinical cues and pathophysiology.

clinicalPearls: Pause before you post. If you wouldn't say it in the presence of your Board of Nursing, don't post it.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that removing a name is NOT enough for HIPAA. If the situation is unique enough to be identifiable, it's a violation. Avoid all patient stories on personal social media.

mnemonic.title: P-O-S-T
mnemonic.expansion: Privacy (HIPAA), Off-duty conduct matters, Standards (NCSBN), Total professionalism.

reviewUnits.heading: Social Media Ethics for Nurses
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must maintain professional boundaries in the digital world. Online lateral violence or patient privacy breaches can lead to disciplinary action and loss of licensure.
reviewUnits.source: ANA Code of Ethics with Interpretive Statements
